questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with intermittent episodes of dizziness for the past few weeks, lasting for a few hours at a time. He also complains of ringing and fullness in his right ear. Rinne's test is positive bilaterally and the Weber test shows lateralization to the left ear. He works as a school teacher and gets vertiginous episodes with loud noise such as the ringing of the bell. Which of the following terms can be used to describe this symptom?
questions.solution:
Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes associated with exposure to loud noise in a patient with Meniere's disease. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear.

Treatment of Meniere's disease includes Betahistine. It acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit vestibular nuclei activity. Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are-

  • Prochlorperazine is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide, an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

Other options- 

Option A: Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. 

Option C: Lermoyez syndrome includes symptoms of Meniere's disease seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Option D: Vestibular hydrops include typical episodes of vertigo while cochlear function remains intact.

questions.text: An elderly patient complains of dizziness on standing from a seated position and after large meals. Blood pressure in the supine and standing position is found to be 130/88 and 100/70 mm of Hg respectively. Examination is unrevealing and ECG is normal. What is the pathophysiology behind this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with dizziness on standing from a seated position and a drop in systolic and diastolic blood pressures of more than 20 mmHg and more than 10 mmHg, respectively, is indicative of orthostatic hypotension due to age-related decreases in baroreceptor responsiveness. 

Orthostatic hypotension is defined as reduction in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mmHg within 3 min of standing or head-up tilt on a tilt table. It manifests as lightheadedness, dizziness, weakness, difficulty thinking, presyncope (near-faintness), and blurred vision.

On standing, blood is displaced to the lower extremities, reducing venous return to the heart. This leads to a decrease in cardiac output and stimulation of compensatory mechanisms which trigger a reflex increase in sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) outflow.

Orthostatic hypotension is a manifestation of sympathetic (autonomic) failure. Orthostatic hypotension also increases with age because of the reduced baroreflex responsiveness, decreased cardiac compliance, and attenuation of the vestibulosympathetic reflex associated with aging. This is an example of a neurogenic cause of orthostatic hypotension which are aggravated or precipitated by autonomic stressors like a meal, hot bath, or exercise.

In non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension such as hypovolemia, the drop in the blood pressure is accompanied by a compensatory increase in heart rate of >15 beats/min. 

Non-neurogenic causes of orthostatic hypotension include

  • Cardiac pump failure - myocardial infarction, myocarditis, aortic stenosis
  • Hypovolemia - dehydration, diarrhea, hemorrhage
  • Metabolic - adrenocortical insufficiency, pheochromocytoma
  • Venous pooling - sepsis, prolonged standing, or recumbency
  • Medications - alpha-blockers, diuretics, phenothiazines, tricyclic antidepressants

Treatment includes removing reversible causes like drugs causing hypotension. Non-pharmacological interventions include patient education regarding staged moves from supine to upright, raising the head of the bed, and increasing dietary fluid and salt. If these fail, drugs like fludrocortisone and midodrine can be given.

Option A : Increased vasovagal reflex is seen in vasovagal syncope triggered by emotional stressors.

Option C : Bezold-Jarisch reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. 

Option D : Bainbridge reflex is a compensatory increase in heart rate following an increase in cardiac preload. Cardiac preload drops in orthostatic hypotension.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient complains of continuous dizziness and nausea since 3 days that is present at rest and worsens with head movement. Examination findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

At rest : right beating nystagmus on rightward & leftward gaze
Head impulse test : eyes drag off target with corrective saccade to central target when head turned right
Rest of neuro - otologic examination normal
questions.solution:
This scenario is a case of left vestibular neuritis which is characterized by continuous episodes of vertigo that is present at rest and worsens with head movement. Nystagmus occurs spontaneously without head movement, and is unidirectional. Positive (abnormal) head impulse test, lack of skew deviation of the eyes and unidirectional nystagmus differentiates it from central causes of vertigo.

Vestibular neuritis (VN) presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and imbalance. Unlike benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV, Option A), continuous vertigo persists even when the head remains still. Spontaneous unidirectional nystagmus is present, occurring without head movement.

Head impulse test involves the vestibulo-ocular reflex, and is abnormal (positive) in acute peripheral vestibular lesions such as VN. An abnormal test would be eyes dragged off target with corrective saccades back to the target. Eyes focused on the target after head movement would be a normal response. 

Vestibular neuritis resolves spontaneously, but glucocorticoids can improve outcomes if administered within 3 days of symptom onset. Antiviral medications are only suggested for Herpes zoster oticus (Ramsay Hunt syndrome). Vestibular suppressant medications can reduce acute symptoms. Patients should be encouraged to resume normal activity as soon as possible. Vestibular rehabilitation therapy can also be tried.

Central vertigo is indicated by a normal head impulse test, vertical skew deviation and bidirectional nystagmus (direction of saccades changes with gaze direction). Other neurologic features that point to central dysfunction include diplopia, weakness and dysarthria. Older patients with vascular risk factors presenting with acute vestibular syndrome should be evaluated for possibility of a stroke.

Option B: Labyrinthitis causes symptoms of hearing loss along with unilateral vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo and associated nausea and vomiting. Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component, and the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis cause nystagmus to the healthy side. Serous labyrinthitis, which is an irritative lesion, leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

Option D: Meniere's disease arises due to the distension of the endolymphatic system. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is generally unilateral.

questions.text: A patient complains of dizziness that is triggered by exposure to loud sounds. This phenomenon is unlikely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The tullio phenomenon, which is vertigo triggered by loud sounds is not seen in otosclerosis.

Tullio phenomenon describes the vertiginous episodes, unsteadiness, nausea, and nystagmus when exposed to loud sounds or noise. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

This is seen in cases of Meniere's disease. It is also seen whenever there is a third mobile window lesion such as otic syphilis, perilymph fistula, and dehiscence of semicircular canals. Vestibular activation can result from a breach in the bony capsule of semicircular canals, which redirects a portion of sound or pressure to the semicircular canals. 

Otosclerosis is the disease of the bony labyrinth in which a normally dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by irregularly laid spongy bone. It is more commonly seen in females between 20-30 years of age and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy and menopause.

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis willisii (better hearing in noisy surroundings than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch.

Other options :

Option A: Otosyphilis results in fistulae formation in the labyrinth leading to Tullio phenomenon.

Option B: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome occurs due to the third window effect created by the dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. It is usually diagnosed in middle-aged individuals. Etiology may be congenital or acquired from cranial trauma.

Option C: A perilymph fistula is an abnormal connection between the inner ear and middle ear, resulting in leakage of perilymph from the cochlea or vestibule. This most commonly occurs through the round or oval window. Causes include post-stapedectomy, ear surgery with dislocation of the stapes, head trauma, and inner ear injury due to forceful Valsalva or barotrauma.

questions.text: A 25 year old male patient comes to the emergency room with complaints of dizziness, neck pain and headache since the past 2 hours following neck trauma. Damage of which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This is a case of vertebral artery dissection characterized by dizziness, severe headache and neck pain following neck trauma. 

Vertebral artery dissection (VAD) is a common cause of stroke in patients younger than 45 years. It can occur spontaneously, but incidental minor trauma and neck distortion caused by chiropractic manipulation, bending of the neck, or blunt trauma causes the dissection. Patients complain of severe neck pain, headache, and dizziness/vertigo following precipitating factors.

VAD is visualized on MR angiography and CT angiography. VAD is treated with anticoagulants such as heparin to prevent stroke. Thrombolysis can be started within 4.5 hours of symptom onset if there are no contraindications.

VAD occurs due to an intimal tear and arterial blood dissecting into the layers of the arterial wall causing hematoma and clot formation. This causes stenosis, compromised arterial blood flow and thromboembolism leading to symptoms of VAD and stroke. Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) and cerebellar infarctions are the most common location for strokes.

Vertebral artery anatomy

The vertebral artery arises from the first part of the subclavian artery. It passes through the foramina of transverse processes of C6 to C1 and enters the cranium through the foramen magnum. The vertebral arteries of both sides join to form the basilar artery. It is divided into four parts:

The first part, V1, begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side. 

The second part, V2 is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae till C2. 

The third part, V3 is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle. 

The fourth part, V4 pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons. 

Other options 

Option A : Carotid artery dissection (CAD) is a tear in the intimal layer of the carotid artery creating an intramural hematoma which can cause stenosis and thrombosis. CAD can occur spontaneously or following trauma (e.g, blunt, chiropractic manipulation, whiplash injury). Patients present with headache, neck pain, ipsilateral horner syndrome, transient ischemic attack or acute stroke. 

Option B : Internal jugular vein (IJV) receives blood from the brain, scalp, face, and neck. It is a continuation of the sigmoid sinus and leaves the skull through the jugular foramen. It joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein. IJV is catheterized in central line insertion and is complicated by internal jugular vein thrombosis. IJV thrombosis secondary to infection is known as  lemierre syndrome.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman presents with severe dizziness that has been occurring several times a month for the past year, which are occasionally accompanied by throbbing headaches, nausea and vomiting. She also has a history of headaches characterised by severe throbbing pain on one side of her head, sensitivity to light and sound, nausea and vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely suffering from vestibular migraine, which is characterized by a history of vertigo and migraines.

Vestibular migraine is a type of migraine featuring vertigo episodes, motion intolerance, persistent dizziness and disequilibrium. It is the most common cause of central vertigo in adults and children.

Headaches may or may not occur concurrently with vertigo, and hence it is important to take a thorough history of migraine in the past. 

The diagnostic criteria for vestibular migraine consist of the following:

  • At least 5 episodes of vestibular symptoms of moderate or severe intensity lasting 5 minutes to 72 hours
  • Current or previous history of migraines with or without aura
  • One or more of the following migraine features with at least 50% of vestibular episodes:
    • Headache with at least 2 of the following characteristics : One-sided location, pulsating quality, moderate or severe pain intensity,
    • Photophobia/phonophobia
    • Visual aura
  • Not better accounted for by another diagnosis

The pathophysiology of vestibular migraine is unknown, but the vestibular symptoms may be an aura, an associated symptom, or due to peripheral vestibulopathy.

Migraine is an episodic, unilateral throbbing headache associated with features like sensitivity to light, sound or movement. Nausea and vomiting often accompany the headache. Patient may have aura (classical migraine) in which the headache is preceded by visual or other neurological symptoms, or may not have aura (common migraine). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. The neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine also play a part.

A migraine attack has four phases: premonitory (prodrome), aura, headache and postdrome; each has distinct and sometimes disabling symptoms, which may overlap.

Other options. :

Option B : Basilar migraine is a migraine with predominant brainstem aura. It is associated with brainstem aura symptoms such as vertigo, dysarthria, diplopia, tinnitus, hearing loss, lack of coordination, and loss of consciousness. It is common in adolescent girls.

Option C : Lateral medullary syndrome (wallenberg syndrome) is due to occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery resulting in the following findings :

  • Descending tract and nucleus of cranial nerve V: Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves: Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus solitarius: Ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract: Ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: Contralateral impaired pain and thermal sensation over half of body

Option D : Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. The disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness.

questions.text:
A 65 year old male patient complains of dizziness and tinnitus 1 week after being discharged from the hospital. Medications he received in the hospital are listed below. Which of the following likely contributed to the patient’s current symptoms?
  1. Gentamicin
  2. Metformin
  3. Ibuprofen
  4. Furosemide
  5. Warfarin
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from delayed onset drug induced ototoxicity from gentamicin, ibuprofen, and furosemide use.

Ototoxicity is characterized by high-frequency hearing loss, tinnitus and vestibular dysfunction. Ototoxic drugs can be primarily vestibulotoxic (damage the hair cells of the inner ear) or cochleotoxic. Examples include antimicrobials (gentamicin and streptomycin), diuretics (furosemide) and NSAIDs (ibuprofen). Certain other drugs which cause dizziness or unsteadiness are antihypertensives, labyrinthine sedatives, oestrogen preparations, diuretics, antimicrobials (nalidixic acid, metronidazole) and antimalarials. 

Patients with impaired renal function, elderly (> 65 years), concomitant ototoxic drug use, past aminoglycoside use, and genetic susceptibility to aminoglycosides are at increased risk of ototoxicity. Symptoms of ototoxicity, hearing loss, tinnitus and/or giddiness may manifest during treatment or after completion of the treatment (delayed toxicity). 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin.  Streptomycin, gentamicin and tobramycin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 

Other options : 

Metformin (2) and warfarin (5) are not known to be ototoxic.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presents with dizziness and fatigue during a marathon. The patient is oriented and diaphoretic. Vitals reveal heart rate of 100/min, blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg and temperature of 101 °F. ECG is normal. His condition improves gradually after IV fluids. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of dizziness, fatigue, hypotension, preserved thermoregulatory control (temperature < 105 °F) and absence of central nervous system dysfunction following endurance exercise (marathons) and exposure to high ambient temperature most likely points to a diagnosis of heat exhaustion.

Heat exhaustion is caused by excessive exposure to heat, leading to nausea, vomiting, dizziness, thirst, fatigue, headache, sweating, and decreased urine output. Body temperature may rise but does not exceed 40.5°C (105°F). Heat exhaustion is distinct from heat stroke as the body maintains thermoregulation and no CNS dysfunction occurs. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent progression to life-threatening heat stroke. Diagnosis involves ruling out heat stroke.

Heat stroke (Option A) is characterized by a raised core temperature of  > 40.5°C [105°F] due to loss of thermoregulatory function and failure of sweating. Predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism. Heat stroke can be of two types:

  • Classic heat stroke (CHS) seen in those with chronic diseases who are predisposed to heat-related illnesses. 
  • Exertional heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. 

Heat stroke usually presents as a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. Tachypnea (rapid Kussmaul breathing), tachycardia, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure are other findings.

CNS dysfunction includes delirium, coma, and convulsions. Thermal cardiomyopathy and heat-related reversible increase in cardiac biomarker levels are also seen. ECG findings include tachyarrhythmias, nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and heat-related ischemia or infarction. Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

Heat stroke is managed by rapid cooling, continuous monitoring with a rectal thermistor (flexible thermometer), fluid resuscitation and correction of electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypoglycemia).

Other options : 

Option C: Heat syncope (exercise associated collapse) is when the patient collapses following endurance exercise or prolonged standing in the heat. Heat stress causes relative volume depletion, decreased vasomotor tone, and peripheral vasodilation. This results in decreased venous return and postural hypotension, especially in nonacclimated elderly individuals. After removal from heat source, most patients recover promptly with cooling and rehydration. 

Option D: Heat cramps are painful muscle spasms caused by the loss of water and salt in high temperatures due to profuse sweating.

Related Pearl: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text:
A patient comes with complaints of dizziness and is found to have unidirectional nystagmus on examination. Suspecting a peripheral cause of vertigo, which of the following would you consider in the differential diagnosis?
  1. Acoustic neuroma
  2. Meniere's disease
  3. Basilar migraine
  4. Vestibular neuronitis
  5. Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
questions.solution:
Acoustic neuroma, Meniere's disease, and vestibular neuronitis are examples of peripheral causes of vertigo as they involve the vestibular end organs and vestibular nerve.

Disorders of the vestibular system cause vertigo and are divided into peripheral and central causes. Peripheral causes of vertigo involve the internal ear and vestibular nerve before it enters the brainstem. Vertigo is the most common cause of dizziness and refers to a sense of spinning or other motion that may be physiological, occurring during/after a sustained head rotation, or pathological, due to vestibular dysfunction. It is due to the asymmetry of vestibular inputs from the two labyrinths or in their central pathway.

Central causes of vertigo are associated with other central nervous system signs such as dysarthria, diplopia, and ataxia. 

Vertigo is also associated with nystagmus which is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory. The following features can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus.

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight

 

Basilar migraine: This is typically considered a central, not a peripheral, cause of vertigo. It's associated with migraine headaches and is characterized by brainstem aura symptoms. Therefore, it should not be included in the differential for a peripheral cause of vertigo.


Vertebrobasilar insufficiency: Like basilar migraine, vertebrobasilar insufficiency is a central cause of vertigo. This would not be typically included in a differential diagnosis focusing on peripheral causes of vertigo.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of episodic dizziness, right-sided facial weakness, tinnitus, and progressive hearing loss. A reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane which blanches on applying pressure. It was removed surgically and the histopathology showed the following slide. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in the above case is a Glomus tumor.

Glomus tumor is an extremely vascular benign tumor. Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear. It originates from the glomus bodies and consists of paraganglionic cells from the neural crest. It is a nonencapsulated tumor and a locally invasive tumor. 

Glomus tumor is most often seen in women in the fourth to fifth decade of life.

A patient typically presents with progressive conductive hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, dizziness, and facial paralysis. If the tumor presents as a polyp, a history of spontaneous bleeding from the ear is seen.

Otoscopy examination shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane as a "rising sun" appearance since the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear.

Clinical and radiological features are enough to arrive at a diagnosis. Treatment consists of:

  • Surgical removal.
  • Radiation.
  • Embolization.
  • Combination of the above

These tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. They are benign but extremely painful due to abundant nerve fibers.

Histopathology shows branching vascular channels separated by stroma containing glomus cells in nests:

Other Options :

Option A: Hemangioendothelioma is a malignant neoplasm arising from the vascular endothelium of long bones.

Option B: Capillary hemangioma shows thin-walled capillaries with scant stroma on histology.

questions.text: An elderly patient with known cardiovascular disease presents with sudden onset vertigo. Suspecting a central cause of vertigo, which of the following features distinguishes lateral pontine syndrome from lateral medullary syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature over body
Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis

questions.solution:
Ipsilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis is seen in lateral pontine syndrome and helps differentiate it from lateral medullary syndrome.

Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Presence of complete ipsilateral facial palsy indicates a LMN lesion which inturn points towards lateral pontine syndrome. If ipsilateral upper facial muscles are spared, this would indicate a UMN lesion, which inturn points towards lateral medullary syndrome.

Ipsilateral manifestations of lateral pontine syndrome include:

  • CN VII: Lower motor neuron facial paralysis
  • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
  • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
  • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Contralateral manifestations of lateral pontine syndrome include loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to lateral spinothalamic tract involvement.

Occlusion of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome. The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body.
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).
  • Ipsilateral upper motor neuron facial paralysis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with major depression presents with a 4-month history of episodic dizziness occurring at rest and exacerbated by standing and watching movies. Blood pressure on sitting and standing remains constant. Examination and imaging findings are normal. If psychosomatic dizziness is suspected, which of the following is indicated?
questions.solution:
SNRIs such as duloxetine are indicated for treating cases of psychosomatic dizziness (persistent postural perceptual dizziness) seen in patients with depression and anxiety, and is characterized by a chronic feeling (>3 months) of fluctuating dizziness that is present at rest and worsens with standing and visual motion (watching movies, shopping in a supermarket). Neurologic examination is normal.

Psychological factors are implicated as a cause of chronic dizziness. Dizziness may be a somatic manifestation of depression, anxiety and panic disorder. Patients with persistent postural perceptual dizziness have chronic fluctuating episodes of dizziness (>3 months) that is present at rest but worse when standing. There is an intensification of symptoms with visual motion (watching movies or shopping in supermarkets). They may also be associated with a past history of vestibular neuritis. 

Neurologic and vestibular examination is normal. Comorbid anxiety disorders can contribute the patients symptoms. 

Patients are treated with SSRIs, cognitive behavioral therapy and vestibular rehabilitation. Vestibular suppressant medications such as meclizine, promethazine and scopolamine should be avoided. 

Disorders of the vestibular system cause vertigo and are divided peripheral and central causes. Peripheral causes of vertigo involve the internal ear and vestibular nerve before it enters the brainstem. Vertigo is the most common cause of dizziness and refers to a sense of spinning or other motion that may be physiological, occuring during/after a sustained head rotation, or pathological, due to vestibular dysfunction. It is due to asymmetry of vestibular inputs from the two labyrinths or in their central pathway.

Vertigo is also associated with nystagmus which is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory.

All options except duloxetine are vestibular suppressants and can be ruled out.

questions.text: A patient complains of imbalance and blurry vision while walking. He was started on gentamicin 1 week ago. Head impulse test is abnormal in both directions and responses to caloric testing are reduced. Apart from discontinuing gentamicin which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This is a scenario of bilateral vestibular hypofunction following gentamicin use and is characterized by complaints of imbalance while walking, blurry vision with head movement (oscillopsia), bilateral abnormal head impulse test, and reduced response to caloric testing. The most appropriate management is vestibular rehabilitation.

Bilateral vestibular hypofunction (BVH) is most commonly caused by vestibulotoxic effects of aminoglycosides such as gentamicin. Clinical signs of vestibulotoxicity occur about a week after gentamicin administration. Bedside tests of vestibular function such as assessment of dynamic visual acuity and head impulse test should be performed daily to stop gentamicin if vestibulotoxicity occurs. 

Causes of BVH include : 

  • Idiopathic
  • Part of a neurodegenerative disorder
  • Iatrogenic (medication ototoxicity)
  • Other causes: degenerative diseases of the cerebellum, meningitis, systemic autoimmune diseases, trauma, bilateral Ménière disease, and bilateral vestibular schwannomas (neurofibromatosis type 2)

Bilateral loss of vestibular function leads to oscillopsia (blurry vision with head movements), gait disturbances, and loss of balance (especially in the dark). Patients typically do not have vertigo as vestibular function is lost on both sides leading to no asymmetry of vestibular input. 

Examination findings of BVH include diminished dynamic visual acuity due to loss of stable vision when the head is moving, abnormal head impulse test in both directions, Romberg sign, and reduced responses to caloric testing. 

Apart from discontinuing the offending drug, current therapy for BVH is vestibular rehabilitation therapy. Vestibular suppressant medications such as meclizine and promethazine should not be used (Option A), as they will increase the imbalance. 

Vestibular rehabilitation therapy (VRT) is a specialized form of physical therapy designed to alleviate imbalance and dizziness associated with vestibular disorders. It involves a series of exercises that help to retrain the brain and vestibular system to compensate for any damage or dysfunction.

Other options : 

Option C: Vestibular implants hold future potential as a treatment, but are not currently indicated.

Option D: The patient's condition may gradually improve by observation alone but vestibular rehabilitation therapy helps improve symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, tinnitus and hearing loss. He has a history of resolved interstitial keratitis in the past. Which of the following serologic tests should be negative to consider a diagnosis of Cogan's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Free treponemal antigen absorption test (FTA-Abs) should be done to rule out otosyphilis to make a diagnosis of Cogan syndrome, which is an autoimmune condition characterized by interstitial keratitis, hearing loss, tinnitus and vestibular symptoms such as vertigo.

Cogan’s syndrome is an autoimmune vasculitis syndrome that presents as interstitial keratitis, vestibuloauditory symptoms (vertigo, tinnitus, and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss), and systemic vasculitis, particularly aortitis with aortic valve involvement. Otosyphilis presents similarly with interstitial keratitis, vertigo, tinnitus and hearing loss. Serology for syphilis, which is an exclusion criterion, must be negative for making a diagnosis of Cogan syndrome.

Ocular and inner ear findings in Cogan's syndrome occur simultaneously or within 6 months of each other. Ocular complaints include photophobia, blurred vision, lacrimation, and pain. Onset is usually sudden, and resolution is gradual with the possibility of future recurrences.

Cogan's syndrome is hypothesized to be an autoimmune etiology. Risk factors include recent upper respiratory tract infection or Chlamydial infection, as raised chlamydial antibody titres have been reported during active disease (Option B). 

Findings on evaluation include the presence of antinuclear antibodies (Option C), anti-smooth muscle antibodies, lupus anticoagulants, cryoglobulins, heat shock protein antibodies, anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies (Option D), or rheumatoid factor (RF). Direct antibodies against the inner ear and corneal antigens are also reported.

Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment. Infliximab has been shown to improve vestibuloauditory functions in cases refractory to steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is common to both benign positional paroxysmal vertigo and vestibular neuritis?
questions.solution:
Vertigo with head motion is a characteristic feature of both BPPV and vestibular neuritis.

In BPPV, the vertigo is typically brief and intense lasting a few seconds, and it is triggered by specific head movements. In vestibular neuritis, the vertigo is typically more prolonged, present at rest and worsens by specific head movements.

BPPV is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of transient vertigo (<1 min) triggered by changes in head position relative to gravity. It is caused by dislodged calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) from the utricular macula into one of the semicircular canals, usually the posterior semicircular canal. A diagnosis of BPPV can be made by Dix-Hallpike test and the condition is treated by repositioning maneuvers for the otoconia such as the Epley maneuver.

Vestibular neuritis (VN) is characterized by continuous episodes of vertigo that is present at rest and worsens with head movement. Nystagmus occurs spontaneously without head movement, and is unidirectional. Positive (abnormal) head impulse test, lack of skew deviation of the eyes and unidirectional nystagmus differentiates it from central causes of vertigo.

VN presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and imbalance. Unlike BPPV, continuous vertigo persists even when the head remains still. Vestibular neuritis resolves spontaneously, but glucocorticoids can be given to improve outcomes if administered within 3 days of symptom onset. Vestibular suppressant medications can be given to reduce acute symptoms. Patients should be encouraged to resume normal activity as soon as possible. Vestibular rehabilitation therapy can also be tried.

Other options : 

Option A and D : Vertigo at rest and associated tinnitus is seen in vestibular neuritis, and not in BPPV.

Option B : BPPV typically causes brief episodes of vertigo lasting seconds, while vestibular neuritis typically causes more prolonged episodes of vertigo lasting days to weeks.

questions.text: You are examining a patient with dizziness. The patient is seated and asked to fix on a target. Suddenly turning his head by 15 degrees to the right reveals an inability to fixate on the target with corrective saccades. Which of the following is abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vestibulo ocular reflex (VOR) is abnormal in this patient given an inability to maintain target fixation on sudden head turn.

Stabilization of gaze during head movements is one of the main roles of the vestibular system. This is performed by the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), which moves the eyes in the opposite direction to compensate for head movement. The test performed in this patient is known as a head impulse test that tests the VOR and helps differentiate between central and peripheral causes of vertigo.

Head impulse test involves the vestibulo-ocular reflex, and is abnormal (positive) in acute peripheral vestibular lesions such as vestibular neuritis. An abnormal test would be eyes dragged off target with corrective saccades back to the target. Eyes focused on the target after head movement would be a normal response.

Acute vestibular syndrome due to central causes (cerebellar or brainstem infarct or hemorrhage) may be life-threatening and has to be differentiated from peripheral causes affecting the vestibular nerve or labyrinth (vestibular neuritis). Central vertigo is indicated by a normal head impulse test.

VOR prevents the slipping of the retinal images when the head moves. It moves the eyes at the same speed but in the opposite direction as the head. If an object is being pursued with eye and head movement, vision cancels the vestibulo-ocular reflex to prevent the eyes from moving in the opposite direction as the head. 

VOR is a physiological vestibular nystagmus that forms the basis of caloric test. If cold water is poured into the right ear the patient develops left jerk nystagmus (rapid phase towards the left), while the reverse happens with warm water, i.e. patient develops right jerk nystagmus. It can be remembered by the mnemonic 'COWS' (Cold- Opposite, Warm-Same).

Other options :

Option B : Vestibulo collic reflex is a compensatory response of the neck muscles when head motion is sensed by the vestibular organs.

Option C : Vestibulo spinal reflex stabilizes body posture to head movements.

Option D : Cervico collic reflex is a cervical reflex which is a compensatory response of neck muscles to stabilize the head with body movement.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset vertigo and headache since the past few hours. Blood pressure is 220/120 mm of Hg. Non contrast CT scan is done, shown below. Which of the following examination findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's sudden onset vertigo and headache, along with a region of hyperdensity in the cerebellar hemisphere on non contrast CT point to cerebellar hemorrhage which is characterized by central nystagmus (direction changing), dysarthria, ataxia and vertical skew deviation (Option D).

Cerebellar hemorrhage or hematoma (CBH) is most frequently seen in middle aged and older adults, and can be spontaneous or secondary to stroke, trauma, aneursym, tumor and anticoagulants. Symptoms of CBH include sudden onset vertigo, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, ataxia, dysmetria, dysarthria, nystagmus, weakness or numbness on one side of the body, confusion and loss of consciousness.

CBH is diagnosed using non contrast CT. Neurosurgery should be consulted for large CBH > 3-4 cm or with significant mass effect for hematoma evacuation. Small hematomas with no mass effect can be managed conservatively.

Acute vestibular syndrome due to central causes (cerebellar or brainstem lesion) may be life-threatening and has to be differentiated from peripheral causes. Central vertigo is indicated by a normal head impulse test, vertical skew deviation (vertical misalignment of eyes) and bidirectional nystagmus (direction of saccades changes with gaze direction). Other neurologic features pointing to central dysfunction include diplopia, weakness and dysarthria. Older patients with vascular risk factors presenting with acute vestibular syndrome should be evaluated for possibility of a stroke.

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight


Other options :

Option B: Features of cerebellar lesions include ataxia (uncoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with broad based gait), intention tremors, nystagmus, dysarthria, hypotonia or atonia, dysmetria (inability to judge the force and range of movement), dysdiadokokinesia (failure to perform rapid alternating movements) and rebound phenomenon.

Option C : Patients with cerebellar or vestibular lesions will have a tendency to fall during Romberg's test regardless of whether eyes are open or closed.

questions.text: An airforce pilot presents with sudden onset intermittent hearing loss, dizziness, and tinnitus soon after a flight training exercise. Investigations reveal high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Hennebert sign is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with sudden onset intermittent sensorineural hearing loss, dizziness and tinnitus following a flight training exercise (barotrauma) with dizziness and nystagmus on valsalva maneuver (positive fistula test and hennebert's sign) is suggestive of perilymph fistula.  

A perilymph fistula is an abnormal connection between the inner ear and middle ear, resulting in leakage of perilymph from the cochlea or vestibule. This most commonly occurs through the round or oval window. Causes include post-stapedectomy, ear surgery with dislocation of the stapes, head trauma and inner ear injury due to forceful Valsalva or barotrauma. It can result from sudden pressure changes in the middle ear (e.g. barotrauma, flying, diving, forceful Valsalva) or raised intracranial pressure (weightlifting or vigorous coughing).

A perilymph fistula causes intermittent vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus and sense of fullness in the ear. This can be triggered by fistula test (intermittent pressure over tragus) and the valsalva maneuver. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the temporal bone is highly sensitive for detecting the fistula. Management of perilymphatic fistula can be conservative or surgical. Conservative measures involve avoiding activities that increase inner ear or intracranial pressure.

The sudden onset of symptoms following trauma (barotrauma) and disequilibirum following valsalva maneuver (hennebert's phenomenon) points in favor of perilymph fistula over meniere's disease (option A). Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the affected ear. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) will reveal sensorineural hearing loss. Hennebert’s sign and Tullio phenomenon are also seen in cases of Meniere's disease.

Other options : 

Option C : Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is characterized by conductive hearing loss and noise induced (Tullio's phenomenon) or pressure-induced dizziness (Hennebert's sign). It occurs due to the third window effect created by the thin/dehiscent wall of the superior semicircular canal. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. 

Option D : Vestibular neuritis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea and vomiting. It is not associated with cochlear symptoms like hearing loss and tinnitus.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with dizziness, unsteadiness and difficulty walking since the past few hours. On examination, the child has ataxia, wide-based gait, decreased responsiveness and peri oral rash. His father reports that he has been behaving strangely and was caught bunking school. What is the most likely cause of the child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This is a scenario of toluene inhalation intoxication presenting acutely with neurologic symptoms and signs of symmetric ataxia, wide based gait and peri oral rash (glue sniffer's rash).

Inhalants are compounds like butane, propane, freons and toluene. These are present in household items like glue, paint thinners, whiteners and hairsprays. These compounds are easily available, thus they're easy to abuse.

Inhalant intoxication presents with symptoms like euphoria, agitation, anxiety and decreased responsiveness. The effects last for a few hours after the inhalation. Inhalant use can also acutely cause symmetric ataxia, and long term use is also associated with local perioral dermatitis known as "glue sniffer's rash".

Inhalant intoxication can be harmful as repeated inhalation can lead to hypoxia, coma and long term use has been associated with delirium and dementia.

Use of intoxicants or drugs must be elicited in patient visits to determine early symptoms of mental disorders and functional impairment in pediatric populations. This can be done through a HEADSSS assessment (Home, Education, Activities, Drugs, Sexuality, Suicide/Depression, Safety).

Other toxic causes of ataxia include alcohol, lithium, phenytoin, barbiturates, mercury, gasoline and glue inhalation.

Other options : 

Option A : Friedrich's ataxia would present as chronic ataxia, and not acutely as in this patient. Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder generally occurring in individuals less than 25 years of age. It is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin. Patients present with clinical features of dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, frequent falls, nystagmus, and titubation (nodding head and body movements).

Option C : Postinfectious cerebellitis is a reversible cerebellar ataxia and a rare acute or subacute complication of varicella zoster infection.

Option D : Ataxia telangiectasia is a rare inherited cause of ataxia. Patients present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions associated with deficits in cerebellar function and nystagmus.

questions.text: An elderly male patient comes with complaints of dizziness and a feeling of unsteadiness over the past few months. Examination reveals pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, and mask facies. What is the most specific symptom that can describe dizziness in this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a scenario of parkinsonism characterized by pill-rolling tremor, shuffling gait, and mask facies. Patients with Parkinsonism can complain of dizziness which is better specified as dysequilibrium.

Dysequilibrium can result from anomalies in the brain, cerebellum, spinal cord, or peripheral nerves. It is the feeling of falling or imbalance accompanied by difficulty in standing or walking. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus, Parkinson's disease, cerebellar degeneration or cerebellar stroke, vertebrobasilar insufficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, tabes dorsalis, and diabetes mellitus are common causes.

Patients who claim to be dizzy are actually experiencing vertigo, presyncope, or dysequilibrium, which are different symptoms. Finding the specific symptom helps to focus the evaluation and reduce the range of possible diagnoses.

  Vertigo Near syncope Dysequilibrium
Description Sensation of spinning or motion (when none is occurring) Sensation of impending loss of consciousness or fainting Instability or sensation of falling while seated, standing, or walking
Differential diagnoses BPPV, vestibular neuritis, Meniere's disease, multiple sclerosis, cerebrovascular disease  Cardiac arrhythmias, aortic stenosis, vasovagal syncope, orthostatic hypotension, hypoglycemia Parkinson's disease, cerebellar degeneration, cerebellar stroke, vitamin B12 deficiency, Tabes dorsalis, normal pressure hydrocephalus


Other options :

Option C: Patients are said to have ill-defined light-headedness if they are unable to articulate their complaints of dizziness. Differentials include depression, anxiety, panic attacks, somatization disorder, medications, and subtle presentations of vertigo, near syncope, or dysequilibrium.
